title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 30 [march 1869]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 30 [March 1869]
text: 1869 Feb or March Not MarchtuesdayTuesday 30 My dear waltWalti have just received your letter i was very glad to hear from you it seemed quite long since i had a letter i am glad you have got rid of your cold it has stuck too you pretty long i was glad to get the letter and glad to have what it contained to tell the thruthtruth Edd and i have had to live pretty saving when georgeGeorge went away he didentdidn't leave me any and i hadenthadn't very much and i had the washing to pay for out off it so i told eddEdd last night he should have bread and coffee to day but i gessguess we shantshan't starve every thing is so dear butter 65 cents per lb i dontdon't get much of it meat is cheaper and i like it better i dontdon't know whether georgGeorge will come home this week or not he thought he would when he went away if he could leave) i am pretty well only last sundaySunday morning i hurt my knee i catchedcaught my foot and struck my knee and it got so lame in the coarsecourse of the day i could hardly walk it is a little better at present but is very stiff i thought i was glad georgeGeorge was gone for i couldentcouldn't hardly doodo any thing when i was entirely still it didentdidn't hurt me much but i tryedtried to walk and it hurt me so i had to sit still but i think it will be better soon i have been trying to get things straighenedstraightened up a little prepatory to moving when my knee was so lame i thought what would i doodo if i was so i couldentcouldn't walk but i can walk quite smart to day if i keep my knee straitstraight it hurts me so to bend it) i suppose we shall have to go as soon as the house is in any kind of condition if georgeGeorge comes home i shall get him to have one of the stoves put up to get the wall perfectly dry i dontdon't regret leaving this house when the cellar is open i can smell the dampness up stairs if the door is open they have every kind of stuff down there and the rats has dug so the water comes in every rain i told mrsMrs. steers they ought to open the doors every clear day but she is very much engaged making money to think of any thing she is clever to me but they want the rooms i suppose itsit's natural enoughfenough i have the music marm and the daughter to practice and all) i have had no corresspondencecorrespondence at all only your s dear Walt so i haventhaven't heard from any body only as you say you have had a letter from jeffJeff i should think as mattyMatty is so smart they would keep house) you remember Walt i always said if Grant got to be presedentpresident i hoped he wouldentwouldn't disappoint his party but i dontdon't know i hope he wontwon't but i suppose time will tell)good bie walterWalter dearLWi felt sorry to see so many females discharged Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 30 [March 1869]
